item.title: Death Toll in Peru Rises to 46 Amid Extraordinary Violence
item.description: “What happened yesterday was really a massacre,” said one human rights activist.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Juan Carlos Cisneros/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters gathering on Monday in the Andean region of Puno in support of the ousted president, Pedro Castillo.

item.title: In the Philippines, Marcos and Duterte’s Alliance Revives Old Worries
item.description: The two scions from notorious family dynasties clinched landslide election victories in 2022, but their power balance remains fragile.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr. of the Philippines with Vice President Sara Duterte at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Manila in June.

item.title: This Is What Shanghai’s Covid Outbreak Looks Like
item.description: The Chinese city is being gripped by a massive Covid wave, leading to a surge in hospitalizations and crowded funeral homes.
item.dc:creator: Qilai Shen and David Pierson
item.media:description: Patients and their loved ones in the lobby of a Shanghai hospital on Friday.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops to Start Training on Patriot Missiles in U.S.
item.description: The Ukrainian soldiers will train at Fort Sill in Oklahoma, where American troops learn to operate advanced ground-based air defense systems.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier preparing primer to fire a 152-millimeter howitzer at Russian positions in Pisky, a city in the Donetsk region, on Monday.

item.title: Iran Protests: People Executed or Sentenced to Death in Crackdown
item.description: An updated look at the Iranians who have been hanged, and those on death row, as the government tries to crush a monthslong uprising.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Getty Images; via Amnesty; via Twitter; via Radio Zamaneh
item.media:description: In a one-month period, Majid Reza Rahnavard, Mohammad Mehdi Karami, Mohsen Shekari and Sayed Mohammad Hosseini were executed after fast-tracked trials in Iran.

item.title: The Three North American Leaders Will Speak After Meeting in Mexico
item.description: Economic cooperation, drug trafficking, migration and climate change are key topics for President Biden’s summit with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: ‘Spare,’ by Prince Harry: Book Review
item.description: At once emotional and embittered, the royal memoir is mired in a paradox: drawing endless attention in an effort to renounce fame.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.media:credit: Loic Venance/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Harry (with his brother at far left) following the coffin of their grandmother Queen Elizabeth II during a procession from Buckingham Palace in September 2022.

item.title: With the Return of Netanyahu in Israel, His Family Is Back, Too
item.description: Many Israelis fear that with Benjamin Netanyahu’s return to power at the head of Israel’s most right-wing government, his family members will play an outsize role in his decision making.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife, Sara Netanyahu, in October at a campaign event in Migdal Haemek, Israel.

item.title: What Does It Mean to Provide ‘Security Guarantees’ to Ukraine?
item.description: A postwar Ukraine will want to ensure that Russia does not attack again. But is there anything short of full NATO membership that will satisfy Kyiv and deter Moscow?
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading to the front line in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last month. Without some form of security guarantee for Ukraine after the war, experts say, it is hard to imagine the country will be able to rebuild and avoid future conflicts.

item.title: What Drove the Brazil Riots? Mass Delusion and Conspiracy Theories
item.description: Sunday’s riot laid bare a daunting threat to Brazilian democracy: Unlike past putsch attempts in Latin America, this one was driven by deeply rooted conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government workers cleaning up the grounds of the presidential offices on Monday, a day after they were set upon by a mob.

item.title: Shifting Strategy, Ukraine Goes Toe to Toe With Russia in Bakhmut
item.description: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian military analysts on Friday near Bakhmut, in the country’s east, reviewing videos obtained by drone operators.

item.title: Putin’s Cease-Fire Effort to Divide the West Over Ukraine Fall Flat
item.description: A cease-fire proposal seemingly aimed at splintering Western unity has instead been met with Western escalation, underscoring Moscow’s diplomatic struggles.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian strike hit a vocational school in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Saturday, during Russia’s proposed cease-fire.

item.title: In Power With Netanyahu, Ultra-Orthodox Parties Chart Israel’s Future
item.description: Bolstered by growth in numbers and political influence, ultra-Orthodox parties are pushing for greater autonomy, with potentially far-reaching implications for the country.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election signs urging members of the Haredi community to vote for ultra-Orthodox parties in November in Bnei Brak, Israel.

item.title: Skatepark Near Colosseum Gives Rome a Modern Tourist Spot
item.description: The ancient city’s leaders hope the new recreation area will lure more visitors from abroad. It has already impressed the talent at home.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Stephanie Gengotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rome city officials praise the new skatepark near the Colosseum as the skatepark with the best view in the world.

item.title: Brazil’s Authorities Race to Identify Organizers of Brasília Riot
item.description: With more than 500 people arrested after supporters of Jair Bolsonaro ransacked Brazil’s seats of government, the authorities began to search for those who funded and aided the rioters.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some of the supporters of former president Jair Bolsonaro who were arrested after the attack on Sunday in Brasília were released on Tuesday.

item.title: Prince Harry Skewers Palace Culture With Nicknames and a Dose of Rancor
item.description: Along with the juicy tidbits Prince Harry offers up in his new memoir, there is also a revealing look at how the royal family, and its staff, operate behind closed doors.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display of Prince Harry’s book in the window at Waterstones in Piccadilly, central London.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Shanghai’s Devastating Outbreak
item.description: Also, the eight warmest years on record and a fragile political alliance in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients and their loved ones in the lobby of a Shanghai hospital on Friday.

item.title: Vatican Pledges to Look Into Emanuela Orlandi Disappearance
item.description: Vatican officials said they would reopen a cold case that has gripped Italians, spawned countless theories and been the subject of a Netflix documentary series.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Filippo Monteforte/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pietro Orlandi, the brother of Emanuela Orlandi, a teenager who disappeared in 1983, stands with supporters, family and friends during a sit-in in 2020 in St. Peter’s Square. Their banner reads: “No state, or church can justify criminality. Truth for Emanuela Orlandi.”

item.title: Russia Reports 2022 Deficit of $47 Billion
item.description: The budget gap reached 3.3 trillion rubles, or 2.3 percent of the size of the Russian economy, according to the country’s finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow last October. Russia’s revenues grew last year, but they couldn’t keep pace with spending.

item.title: More than 200 Russian doctors petition Putin to give medical care to Navalny.
item.description: The letter, signed by doctors with their full names, was a rare example of public criticism of the Kremlin in post-invasion Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Alexander Nemenov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Aleksei Navalny being taken from a police station outside Moscow on Jan. 18, 2021, shortly after his return to Russia from Germany, where he had recovered after being poisoned with a nerve agent.

item.title: Britain Is Considering Sending Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: The British Challenger II could become the first Western-made main battle tank to be provided to Ukraine since Russia invaded almost a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Challenger II tank at an arms fair in 2019 in London.

item.title: French Government Unveils Plan to Raise Retirement Age to 64
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is focusing on cutting costs in France’s pension system, but labor unions, which fiercely oppose the measure, have promised a showdown.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Damien Meyer/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A banner bears portraits of Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne, President Emmanuel Macron and Labour Minister Olivier Dussopt. It reads “no pension for the dead people” and was part of a rally on Tuesday against the government’s pension reform plan in Rennes, in northwest France.

item.title: How Finland Is Teaching a Generation to Spot Misinformation
item.description: The Nordic country is testing new ways to teach students about propaganda. Here’s what other countries can learn from its success.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Vesa Laitinen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olli Seppala, from left, Aatu Aho-Mantila and Arttu Hati learned about identifying misinformation in class in Hameenlinna, Finland.

item.title: Robert Moller Dies at 85; Mediated Between U.N. Envoys and the City
item.description: As the U.S. liaison to some 50,000 United Nations diplomats and staff, he sought to resolve disputes on issues ranging from fugitives hiding in U.N. missions to diplomats’ unpaid parking tickets.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: UK Bookstores React to Prince Harry’s Memoir
item.description: While some booksellers said “Spare” had generated a huge number of preorders, the reaction was mixed at stores in London, with some customers dismissive of the latest episode in a mounting royal drama.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Spare,” Prince Harry’s memoir, at a Waterstones bookstore in Trafalgar Square in London on Tuesday. Early-morning lines at sellers in London teemed with journalists, but regular book buyers were slower to file through the doors.

item.title: Jill Biden Focuses Empowerment of Women and Girls During Mexico Trip
item.description: Stressing the importance of economic opportunity, the first lady said empowered women are “the heart of a strong democracy.”
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jill Biden, the first lady, embracing Beatriz Gutiérrez Müller, the first lady of Mexico, at an arrival ceremony with President Biden and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at the National Palace in Mexico City on Monday.

item.title: A Paris Cabaret Makes Way for ‘Cabaret’
item.description: The 1966 American musical has opened at a venue that for decades hosted one of the city’s most famous revue troupes.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle

item.title: Prompted by Russian Aggression, EU and NATO Vow New Cooperation
item.description: A joint declaration on European security, painfully negotiated, underscores that NATO is “the foundation of collective defense.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Stephanie Lecocq/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: From left, Charles Michel, the president of the European Council; Jens Stoltenberg, secretary general of NATO; and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, in Brussels on Tuesday.

item.title: Greece Opens Espionage Trial of Aid Workers Who Helped Migrants
item.description: Sara Mardini, a Syrian refugee turned activist, is among 24 people facing charges. Amnesty International has called the case “farcical.”
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer directing a boat of refugees as they arrived on the Greek island of Lesbos in 2015.

item.title: Brazil and Jan. 6
item.description: How Brazil’s riots compare to the Jan. 6 attack.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Planalto Palace in Brasília, Brazil, on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Carbon Emissions Grew in 2022, Even As Renewables Surpassed Coal
item.description: Emissions ticked up 1.3 percent last year, even as renewables surpassed coal.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Natural gas flaring in an oil field near Andrews, Texas, last year.

item.title: AI Is Becoming More Conversant. But Will It Get More Honest?
item.description: At a new website called Character.AI, you can chat with a reasonable facsimile of almost anyone, live or dead, real or (especially) imagined.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The armies of Russia and Ukraine clash in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian military analysts near Bakhmut.

item.title: In Mexico, Biden Looks for Help With Migrants and Stronger Partnership
item.description: The migration tide loomed large at the president’s summit meeting with the leaders of Mexico and Canada. All three want to steer away from the rancor of the Trump years.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at Felipe Angeles International Airport in Mexico City, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Brazil Arrests Rioters
item.description: Also, heavy fighting rages around Bakhmut and scientists say the ozone layer is healing.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Facade of the Planalto Palace (presidential office) vandalized by demonstrators supporting former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro in Brasilia, Brazil, on Monday.

item.title: Prince Harry Memoir Signals Bigger Royal Rift
item.description: The self-exiled royal has given the world a warts-and-all look at his family — with an emphasis on the warts.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: Prince Harry, Meghan, King Charles and his wife, Camilla, at the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II in September.

item.title: Adolfo Kaminsky Dies at 97; His Forgeries Saved Thousands of Jews
item.description: His talent for creating realistic documents helped children, their parents and others escape deportation to concentration camps, and in many cases to flee Nazi-occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.media:credit: Joël Saget/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Adolfo Kaminsky at his home in Paris in 2012. After his wartime exploits in forgery, he became a photographer and photography teacher.

item.title: What We Know About Investigations Into the Brazil Protests
item.description: Investigators face several major questions as they piece together how rioters briefly seized the seats of Brazil’s government.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: The facade of the Federal Supreme Court on Monday, after anti-democracy riots in Brasília.

item.title: Czech Court Clears Andrej Babis of Fraud in E.U. Funds Case
item.description: Andrej Babis, a billionaire agriculturalist, had been accused of illegally obtaining farm subsidies for one of his properties.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Barbora Petrova
item.media:credit: Martin Divisek/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Andrej Babis, who is running for president, was cleared in a case revolving around his use of the E.U. farm subsidy program, a pot of money worth dozens of billions.

item.title: Has Prince Harry’s ‘Spare’ Changed Public Opinion of Him?
item.description: Even in the United States, which has a high tolerance for redemptive stories about overcoming trauma and family dysfunction, the tide seems to be turning.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Harry’s memoir, “Spare,” went on sale early in Spain, where it was snapped up and translated by alert members of the British media.

item.title: French Food Giant Danone Sued Over Plastic Use Under Landmark Law
item.description: Environmental groups are relying on a law in France requiring large companies to address their environmental footprint.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Thierry Zoccolan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Production of Volvic mineral water at a French factory. The brand is part of Danone, which environmental groups say is not doing enough to reduce its use of plastics.

item.title: Restoration of the Ozone Layer Is Back on Track, Scientists Say
item.description: Rogue emissions from China of ozone-depleting chemicals had threatened to delay recovery by a decade. But the emissions were stopped, according to a U.N.-backed report.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refrigerator factory in 2018 in Xingfu, China, an area that defied restrictions on ozone-depleting CFC-11 until a government crackdown.

item.title: Ukraine Rejects Russia’s Claim of 600 Killed in Kramatorsk Attack
item.description: Russia’s Defense Ministry said it had carried out a strike that “killed 600 people,” but no evidence has emerged to support the claim.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crater outside a vocational school in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Sunday after Russian strikes.

item.title: Could Congressional Gridlock Lead to More Government Shutdowns?
item.description: Congressional gridlock brought on by far-right Republicans now seems more likely to lead to government shutdowns.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin McCarthy.

item.title: Here’s the latest on the riot in the Brazilian capital.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas

item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ueslei Marcelino/Reuters

item.title: What We Learned From Prince Harry’s ITV and ‘60 Minutes’ Interviews
item.description: Two days before the publication of his memoir, “Spare,” Harry appeared at ease and at times emotional in high-profile interviews in the United States and Britain.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: 60 Minutes
item.media:description: In an interview for “60 Minutes,” Prince Harry, right, spoke to Anderson Cooper.

item.title: Brazil’s Protests Resemble the US Capitol Attack on Jan. 6
item.description: Jair Bolsonaro, the right-wing former president of Brazil, had for months sought to undermine the results of an election that he lost, in much the same manner that Donald J. Trump did after his defeat in the 2020 presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Leah Millis/Reuters
item.media:description: Supporters of U.S. President Donald J. Trump gathered outside the Capitol in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: Videos Show How Rioters Stormed Brazil’s Capital
item.description: Watch key moments of rioters attacking Brazil’s Congress, Presidential offices and the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Axel Boada, Scott Reinhard, Jack Nicas, André Spigariol and Nailah Morgan
item.media:credit: Satellite image by Planet Labs

item.title: Bolsonaro Supporters Lay Siege to Brazil’s Capital
item.description: Backers of former President Jair Bolsonaro ransacked government offices, denouncing what they falsely claim was a rigged election. Hundreds were arrested.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Evaristo Sa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Irate supporters of Jair Bolsonaro, the former president, swarm federal government offices in Brasília on Sunday.

item.title: Who Is Jair Bolsonaro?
item.description: The former president of Brazil upended political norms as a far-right populist.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Jair Bolsonaro in Brasília in October last year.

item.title: Bernard Kalb, Veteran Foreign Correspondent, Is Dead at 100
item.description: He covered wars, revolutions and diplomatic breakthroughs for CBS, NBC and The New York Times. He also served, briefly and unhappily, as a State Department spokesman.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Hevesi
item.media:credit: CBS, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Kalb in the CBS newsroom in 1972. He worked for the network from 1962 to 1980 and then joined NBC as the State Department correspondent.

item.title: Biden, World Leaders Condemn Brazil Protests
item.description: Leaders from the United States, Latin America and Europe expressed support for Brazil’s president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Adriano Machado/Reuters
item.media:description: Supporters of Brazil’s former President Jair Bolsonaro demonstrate against President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, in Brasilia on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: China Reopens
item.description: Also, Brazilians storm government offices and the Times investigates a 2021 Kabul airstrike.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Noel Celis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People embracing at the international arrivals gate at Beijing International Airport on Sunday, after China opened its borders.

item.title: Former President Bolsonaro Is in Florida as Protests Take Place in Brazil
item.description: Before departing Brazil, the former president had urged his supporters to avoid violence.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Skyler Swisher/Orlando Sentinel, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Former President Jair Bolsonaro has been staying in Orlando, Fla. Last week, supporters held a rally for him there.

item.title: Here’s what to know about the protest fueled by false claims of electoral fraud.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol

item.title: Bus Crash in Senegal Kills at Least 40
item.description: The president of the West African country announced three days of national mourning for the victims.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Cheikh Dieng/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A bus crash on Sunday in central Senegal killed at least 40 people.

item.title: Family in Ukraine Marks Orthodox Christmas Amid the Ruins of Its Home
item.description: Orthodox Christmas came under harsh circumstances in Ukraine this year. For families like the Kovtuns, living next to the remains of their shell-struck home, celebration was an act of defiance.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oksana Kovtun preparing a Christmas Eve meal. The power went out in the family’s temporary home in Makariv, Ukraine, two hours before dinner on Friday.

item.title: How the Student Murders Have Affected Life in Moscow, Idaho
item.description: Horrific slayings brought grief and anxiety to a the placid college town of Moscow, Idaho.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Margaret Albaugh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in front of the house where four students were killed, near the University of Idaho.

item.title: Now Fighting for Ukraine: Volunteers Seeking Revenge Against Russia
item.description: Chechens, Crimean Tatars and people from the former Soviet republics, all with deep historical grievances against Moscow, are eagerly taking up arms for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer Chechen battalion training last month outside Kyiv, Ukraine.
